docs.title: 3. Addressing Gaps
docs.text: The section will check if the insurance company has thought of ways to detect and address potential the mismatch between the index and their losses. It will also estimate the gap due to this misalignment in monetary value to guide any efforts to compensate farmers for losses not covered by the index.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
• Do you have a system in place to detect the mismatch? How would you detect it? (e.g., farmer hotline to request for an audit, scheduled visits to farmers, etc.)
  • What grievance and remedy mechanisms do you have in place to ensure payouts align with actual farmer losses or compensate farmers for actual losses, if any? (e.g., ex-gratia payments, satellite-based plus audits, contingency fund, etc.)
  • How big is the gap between what payouts would have been and farmer payout expectations in monetary value? Is this a gap you could include in the design of the product?

docs.title: 2. Alignment of Payouts with Farmer Losses
docs.text: The section will look at how well the chosen index for the insurance matches farmer's experience of losses. There is a follow up question for weather-based index insurance around when measurements will be taken since this decides payout.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
• How well does what payouts would have been align with farmer payout expectations based on your chosen index? How often does payout align and not align with farmer expectation? (weather-based and area-yield index insurance)*
  • During which part/s of the season will satellite or rainfall measurements be taken to determine payouts (for weather-based index insurance)? What sources will you base these on?

docs.title: 5. Farmer communication
docs.text: This section will assess the company’s work in 1) communicating and educating farmers about insurance, 2) monitoring outputs from these communication and training efforts, and 3) handling complaints and grievances, to make the insurance product truly valuable for farmers. These questions will primarily be qualitative with verification through submission of documents (training plans, questionnaires, etc.)

docs.title: Communications Strategy
docs.text:
• In the past, have you established ways to communicate and train farmers about their insurance? If yes, who did the communication and training? What activities were done?
  • For the proposed product, what is your planned communication and training strategy? Who will do the communication and training? What activities will be done?

docs.title: Monitoring Strategy
docs.text:
• In the past, did you check that farmers understood that they had insurance and what they can expect from the product? If yes, how did you do so?
  • For the proposed product, how do you plan to check that farmers understand the insurance and set their expectations about the product?

docs.title: Grievance and remedy mechanisms:
docs.text:
• In the past, did you have grievance and remedy mechanisms in place for farmers who experience losses but did not receive payouts? If yes, what mechanisms did you have in place?
  • For the proposed contract, what grievance and remedy mechanisms will you put in place for farmers who experience losses but did not receive payouts?

docs.title: 1. Insurance Program Structure and Providers
docs.text: The Assessment will begin with a series of qualitative questions that will 1) identify what the insurance program aims to achieve and set the baseline for evaluating responses throughout the assessment, and 2) gather background of the Providers

docs.title: 4. Payout Value, Size and Frequency
docs.text: This section will look at how much farmers are getting for what they pay and whether insurance companies are getting enough payments to finance payouts using a simple calculator. It will also initiate discussions on the appropriate size and frequency of insurance to set farmer expectations on payouts.

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
• How much of the money farmers pay is expected to be paid out?
  • What is the expected size and frequency of payouts?
  • Is the premium affordable for farmers?
